title: Search behaviors
content:
Service Management implements different search policies and strategies in different locations within its various search UI areas.

Global search in Service Portal/Service Management/Live Support

This table compares the different search behaviors in Service Portal, Service Management (Agent interface), and Live Support.

Service Portal Service Management (Agent interface) Live Support
Number of searchable record types

10, including:

  • Article
  • News
  • QNA
  • ServiceOffering
  • SupportOffering
  • HumanResourceOffering
  • ServiceRequest
  • SupportRequest
  • HRRequest
  • Idea

  • AccountingPeriod 
  • ActualService 
  • Article

  • Brand
  • Budget

Minimum search result relevance threshold

Based on the value specified in Smart Analytics settings

Default: 30

 30 10
Maximum number of search results returned 30 30 50
Only return results requested by/for the user who's searching Yes No No
Restricted by entitlement rules Yes No No

Note: Some record types might not be applicable depending on the license assigned to the tenant. 

Global search in Service Portal

In Service Portal, requests, offerings, knowledge articles, news, ideas, and Q&A entries are searchable.

  • Requests: End users can view entitled public requests, as well as requests submitted by themselves or submitted for them.
  • Offerings: End users can only view active and entitled offerings.
  • Knowledge articles: End users can only view external and active and entitled knowledge articles.
  • Service Portal also uses a learning feature to provide search results that include offerings used in requests related to the search query.

Global search in Service Management

As shown in the above table, more record types are searchable in Service Management than in Service Portal. Additionally, tenant administrators can now enable Global search for custom or more OOTB record types by configuring index fields.

Agents can view all requests and offerings if they match the keyword and have a high rank, regardless of the Requested by or Requested for person configured in the ticket.

If a request has lower relevance to keywords in other records (such as Incident), then the request might not show up. This is because the results will show other record types as well. In other words, higher relevancy matches from other records will obscure lower-ranked request matches. However, when doing a global search, agents can also specify the record types. If requests are the desired record type, the agent can indicate this in the search filter.

Search in Live Support

Search in Live Support is designed to help agents search for solutions to resolve a ticket. There are two types of searches on the live support page:

  • The upper part allows a database search by selecting a person or a location. In either case, a database query is issued to select matching requests where the Requested by or the Location field matches the search selection value. For example, if you select a person, you will see a list of recent requests submitted by this person.
  • The lower part allows an Intelligent Data Operating Layer (IDOL) based search over a limited set of record types. This search has a lower matching threshold that allows 50 search results, compared with 30 results for global search in Service Management.

The following table summarizes the differences between these two types of searches:

Filter

Search

Search content

Records in transaction databases

Records indexed by IDOL

Latency

No

The records become searchable right after they're created in the database.

Yes

The records aren't searchable until you create a document index in IDOL.

Search criteria

Structured queries (SQL), most complex and accurate

Keyword-based search

For more information about Live Support search, see How to deal with a Live Support call.

Indexed fields

Only a selected number of fields can be used for keyword-based searches. Currently, these OOTB fields aren't configurable on UI. However, you can add new index fields to meet your business needs.

Most of the record types indexed in IDOL are searchable by using Title, Description, and ID. Besides these fields, you can also search different record types with other indexed fields. The following table lists some fields you can use to search certain record types. Go to Studio for a full list of the indexed fields applicable for each record type.

Record type Applicable indexed fields
Person
  • First name
  • Last name
  • Name
  • Employee number
  • Email
  • Office phone number
  • Mobile phone number
Offering Public comments
Article

Tags

For how to use this field, see Create or update a knowledge/news article.
Request
  • Public comments
  • Actual service ID
  • Category ID
  • Involved device ID
Incident
  • Category ID
  • Actual service ID or display label
  • Involved device ID
Change
  • Actual service ID or display label
  • Category name
  • Involved device ID
  • Change model name
  • Sub category
  • Priority
  • Phase
Actual Service
  • Global ID
  • Environment
  • Subtype
  • Support group
Device
  • Global ID
  • OS type
  • Environment
  • Subtype
  • Phase
  • Model
  • Hardware and software information

Why search results don't match the search keyword

Sometimes, a search might return results that don't seem to match the required keyword. For example, if you search "printer", a seemingly irrelevant result such as "order laptop backpack" might appear. This is because some indexed fields other than Title, Description, and ID are used to search for the keyword.

To find the indexed field that matches the search keyword, follow these steps:

  1. Go to the saw-dah log folders (/var/vols/itom/itsma/smartanalytics-volume/logs/idol/saw/dah/smarta-saw-dah-<n>), and find the action.log file.
  2. Open the file and locate the action that has the maxresult=60 string. The Text field indicates the search keyword.
  3. Copy the entire action and use a URL decoding tool to decode this query.
  4. Remove responseFormat=json& from the decoded query, and then copy the query to a text editor.
  5. Go to Service Management, select Configurations > Smart Analytics, and then click GO TO SMART ANALYTICS.
  6. In Smart Analytics Assistant, double-click XService DAH, and then replace action=GetStatus in the text box with your decoded query.
  7. Run this action to get the response result.
  8. Search printer in the result. You will find the indexed field that contains your keyword. In this example, it's the PUBLIC-COMMENTS field.
